title: Perforated Peptic Ulcer
diagnosis_topic: Full-thickness gastric or duodenal ulcer resulting in peritonitis
setup_script: A 50-year-old man with a history of NSAID use presents with sudden, severe epigastric pain that radiates to the back. He appears ill and has a rigid abdomen.

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 90/60 mmHg, HR 120 bpm, RR 24/min, Temp 38 C.
Board-like rigidity with diffuse rebound tenderness; absent bowel sounds.
WBC 18 K/uL, lactate elevated at 4 mmol/L; hemoglobin normal.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident obtains upright chest and abdominal X-ray
dynamic_flow.reply: Free air under the diaphragm indicating perforated viscus.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident resuscitates with IV fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics
dynamic_flow.reply: Start piperacillin-tazobactam and fluid bolus; NPO with NG tube to decompress stomach.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident consults surgery for emergent operative management
dynamic_flow.reply: Laparoscopic or open Graham patch repair with omental patch performed; irrigation of peritoneal cavity.
Open surgery may be preferred for rapid access and ability to address bleeding or malignancy.
Peritonitis and sepsis worsen, increasing mortality.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident administers proton pump inhibitors and tests for Helicobacter pylori postoperatively
dynamic_flow.reply: Start PPI therapy and arrange H. pylori eradication if positive.
Selected in stable patients with contained leak and no peritonitis; includes antibiotics, PPI and close monitoring.
Avoid NSAIDs, use PPI prophylaxis in the future and discuss risk factors such as smoking and H. pylori infection.
Watch for leak, abscess, bleeding and nutritional deficiencies in case of gastric resection.

critical_decision_points: Rapid diagnosis of perforated peptic ulcer via exam and imaging
Immediate resuscitation and initiation of antibiotics and gastric decompression
Timely surgical intervention with omental patch repair
Recognition of indications for non-operative management and its limitations
Postoperative management including PPI therapy and H. pylori eradication
